conclusion: Determine the electric force experienced by the small ball at point B.
Small ball released from rest at point A moves along the tube to point B.
Electric field due to charges at points M and N must be considered at point B.
Charges at points M and N are +Q and -Q, forming an equilateral triangle with side length L.
Distance between M and N is L.
Electric field at point B due to a point charge Q at distance r is E = kQ/r^2.
Electric fields due to charges at M and N cancel each other out in the horizontal direction at point B.
Net electric field at point B will only have a vertical component.
Vertical component of electric field due to a point charge Q at distance r is E_y = kQ/r^2 * cos(theta).
Distance r_1 from M to B is L/sqrt(2).
Vertical component of electric field due to charge +Q at M is kQ/(L^2 sqrt(2)).
Distance r_2 from N to B is L/sqrt(2).
Vertical component of electric field due to charge -Q at N is -kQ/(L^2 sqrt(2)).
Net vertical electric field at point B is 0.
No vertical electric force on the small ball at point B.
Magnitude of the electric force experienced by the small ball at point B is 0.
